black up hey I hope everyone is doing
well doing good
Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's
busiest music nerd it's time for an
album review Shabazz Palaces black up as
far as I can tell
Shabazz Palaces is a hip hop project led
by Pallas ear Lazaro but that's not his
real name he's actually Ishmael Butler
who used to be in the 90s hip-hop outfit
digital planets but you don't need to
hear that stuff to enjoy this palace ear
also brings on some collaborators for
this LP but as far as I can tell they
are anonymous or working under
pseudonyms that I saw listed out on a
sub pop Records website if anything you
should try to check out the to self
releases that Shabazz put out before
this new LP black up and how to attack
this because there are so many things to
say about it let's start with the beats
and the production because it's such a
vital part to this album I would say
more so than a lot of hip-hop albums and
I say that because there are so many
points where the textures and the
effects and the samples and the beats
basically take over and maybe drown out
the lyricism a little bit and kind of
make it play second fiddle but I love
the way this thing sounds it's it's
really something else if you don't have
this LP on a big-ass stereo you're
really only hearing half the story
because some of the drums some of the
low-end some of the kicks on this are
really really nice not a lot of release
on the drums they're very lean they're
very kind of sharp guts but very hard
clicky clicky the low-end Rumble shake
the ground the the highs are nice and
crisp and an atmospheric the samples are
cut really well the effects are executed
with finesse
and this thing is mixed like a monster
unless a track is going for a very
cacophonous wall of sound it's very
clear it's very well balanced some of
the beats here are just a really nice
straightforward enjoyable no-brainer
like were you can you are you felt are
you can you where you felt just a really
nice droning string sample stuttering
jazz piano chords a boom click beat a
very chill laid-back flow the whole
package of it all kind of puts me in a
place that may be listening to Quasimodo
or some other Madlib related album would
but straight-and-narrow is not the game
this LP plays most of the time a lot of
these beats are out there you gotta
trust me on this one each track has like
a plethora of different sounds that I
could go into very great detail with
like the opener free press and curl very
eerie bass hums on that track just
sputtering cymbal hits flying all over
both mix channels there are a lot of
effects being used on Pallas ears voice
as the as the song evolves and there are
these vocal samples that are literally
manipulated mauled I would say to the
point where they kind of sound like a
steam train whistle blowing it's weird
another one of my favorite beats is the
second track and it does this trick it
does this little turn of the hand that I
hear on a lot of these tracks that I
haven't heard done quite like this
before
there's a female vocal sample on there
and it is stretched out just
aggressively because it's stretched and
it's not pitch shifted there's all these
like digital stretch marks on edges it's
a noisy sound that maybe another
producer would do his or her best to try
to eliminate or cover up but this LP he
just puts it out in the open
and it's got a pretty surreal quality
their tracks on here loaded with various
synthesizers bleeps and bloops like a
treaty dedicated
and eulogy which that songs first half
is basically a cacophonous wall of
various sounds and noises but there are
tracks here I like a lot that come off
very sparse very empty luckily palace
e'er has enough charisma to me to fill
an entire stadium which is really what
locks me in with a lot of these tracks
I love the Rhymes I love this flow I
just love the personality I love the
delivery but I know it's not going to be
for everybody if you're a boom bap
traditionalist who enjoys a lot of fiery
flows a lot of technical ability then
this is definitely not going to be for
you though there are some very strong
statements made in the lyrics on this LP
it doesn't really go hard while many
rappers are kind of in this bragging
competition this LP is more content kind
of sitting in the stands and meditating
and making fun of albums that fall prey
to clichés like materialism and violence
and swag that Death Grips album I loved
earlier this year made that stuff look
stupid and ugly by taking it to such an
extreme that it couldn't be rationalized
by anybody to be good
this album does the same thing but it
does it in a way that's toned down kind
of in a in a studious way like it would
say these rhymes after closing a book
and looking over from its tipped glasses
this thing is just kind of like a
socially conscious full course meal
about freedom and racism society at
large the Internet age hip hop making
music attracting girls and of course
there's a bunch of abstract stuff on the
menu too like actually one of my
favorite verses the Knights are getting
stronger and the days are getting longer
the building is getting bigger
outside is getting smaller the lives are
getting truer and the truth is getting
brighter
things are looking blacker but black is
looking whiter what weird but I love it
the only thing I'm really kind of mixed
on on the fence with is how these songs
are put together we have ten tracks here
but there are some songs
that could easily be two because they
hit a transitional moment where the
track becomes something completely
different it's not really an evolution
as much as it is like an immediate shape
shift of mood and that's fine it
actually makes this LP kind of a thrill
to listen to because it unfolds it
surprises but there are some songs here
that don't have enough track length to
fully develop the shifts that they make
the track endeavors to me comes off a
little aimless its various parts don't
connect as much as they kind of clash
and the Kings new clothes just kind of
ends and fizzles out for no reason just
as the song sort of seems to be gaining
momentum emotion and a message but
outside of that I'm loving this thing
it's a great reminder of how
mind-altering and up hip-hop music can
be but still sound great while being
those things so I'm kind of feeling a
decent eight on this a decent eight but
let me know what you're thinking of this
are you loving it are you hitting it why
and what should I review next anthony
Fantana Shabazz Palaces black up forever
